ygData.subject: Distributed SharpNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all, I m wanted to let everyone know that I ve finished an initial release of a parallel (distributed really) implementation of SharpNEAT and it s available

Subject: Distributed SharpNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=203001720; y=qPa4UiwiWZO0-4VZ81fGw54DdgRrbGvQ-hmw4cU2QbgDTA
X-Yahoo-Profile: tansey4

Hi all,

I'm wanted to let everyone know that I've finished an initial release of 
a parallel (distributed really) implementation of SharpNEAT and it's 
available on CodePlex (http://www.codeplex.com/parasharpneat).  I tried 
to keep the initial release very focused on how Colin implemented 
SharpNEAT, and I think that creating a distributed experiment which can 
run on multiple nodes should be fairly straight-forward if you're 
familiar with SharpNEAT.  Additionally, I've provided a distributed 
version of the Max Experiment to help people figure out the differences.

The logic from an experiment-creator's viewpoint is 99% the same.  The 
only thing that is really necessary now is that rather than creating one 
of the standard IPopulationEvaluator classes, you create an instance of 
the new DistributedPopulationEvaluator; also, instead of having your 
network evaluator implement INetworkEvaluator, it must now derive 
RemoteNetworkEvaluator.  Conceptually, that's all that you need to know!

I provided a nice little GUI for a worker node to select which network 
evaluator to run.  I wasn't a big fan of how the plug-in architecture 
was implemented in SharpNEAT, so I implemented what I think is a simpler 
and cleaner approach for the new GUI.  This new part requires that a 
RemoteNetworkEvaluator provide a few descriptors like the name of the 
evaluator, the author, etc.  Additionally, since they're plug-ins, 
RemoteNetworkEvaluators should have a default constructor and use the 
Initialize method to perform the setup at the beginning.  All of this is 
demonstrated in the DistributedMaxExperiment.  I plan on implementing 
the same changes to the SharpNEAT GUI, but that is a lower priority than 
some of the other features I want to add (e.g., fault tolerance, adding 
new worker nodes mid-experiment).

The SharpNeatLib code had to be slightly modified with [Serializable] 
attributes on a lot of the classes to enable them to be transmitted by 
copy to the worker nodes.  The modified version is included in the 
CodePlex release.

I've tested it fairly extensively, but this is a first release, so I'm 
sure it's got a few bugs in it that I couldn't catch.  If anyone wants 
to try it out, I'd be glad to hear how/if it works, and of course will 
help with any errors.

-- 

Wesley Tansey
Graduate Student
Department of Computer Science
Virginia Tech
http://people.cs.vt.edu/~tansey/
